entry.title: Be Suspicious of Success
entry.summary: Be Suspicious of Success
entry.content:
An anonymous reader shared this summary from Buttondown:


Successful software is buggy software.


You should be suspicious if [the model checker] does not find a violation of a liveness property... you should also be suspicious if [it] finds no errors when checking safety properties. This is specifically in the context of model-checking a formal specification, but it's a widely applicable software principle. It's not enough for a program to work, it has to work for the right reasons. Code working for the wrong reasons is code that's going to break when you least expect it.



Comments | View Source

entry.content:

I stumbled onto the idea for this app by seeing how much time my wife, who is a YouTube creator who makes videos about learning music theory, spent preparing additional materials to give to her Patreon supporters as an extra "thank you" for supporting her videos. While it would be nice for her to have really good, accurate exact transcripts of her videos, what I thought could be a lot more valuable would be if I could somehow generate really polished written documents, formatted nicely in markdown, that conveyed the same basic information, but in a way that sounded more like a real written article or chapter from a book. And I soon realized that, once you had that "optimized document," you could then use that to generate other useful things such as quizzes...

entry.title: The University of Michigan Doubled Down on DEI What Went Wrong?
entry.summary: The University of Michigan Doubled Down on DEI What Went Wrong?
entry.content:
An anonymous reader quotes a report from The New York Times:


In 2022, the University of Michigan doubled down on its commitment to diversity, equity and inclusion. It was an extraordinary moment for a school that had long been at the center of America's culture wars over affirmative action. But just as it was preparing to unveil its new DEI strategy -- which included hiring hundreds more staff members, expanding programs aimed at underrepresented students and investing millions in scholarships -- the Supreme Court struck down race-conscious admissions policies nationwide.


Suddenly, Michigan's ambitious plans were illegal. And yet they continued anyway: The university forged ahead with many initiatives that would have required consideration of race or ethnicity even after doing so became unconstitutional. This decision has led to lawsuits against Michigan by conservative groups who argue that it is still using racial preferences in violation of federal law.

entry.title: Winamp deletes entire GitHub source code repo after a rocky few weeks
entry.summary: Winamp deletes entire GitHub source code repo after a rocky few weeks
entry.content:
Winamp has deleted its entire GitHub source code repository less than a month after posting it, following backlash from the open-source community over its restrictive licensing terms and concerns about proprietary code being included in the release. Ars Technica reports:


Winamp, through its Belgian owner Llama Group, posted the source for its "Legacy Player Code" on September 24 so that developers could "contribute their expertise, ideas, and passion to help this iconic software evolve." Less than a month later, that repository has been entirely deleted, after it either bumped up against or broke its strange hodgepodge of code licenses, seemingly revealed the source code for other non-open software packages, and made a pretty bad impression on the open-source community... Justin Frankel said on his Q&A site about contributing to the code. Frankel responded that, even if he had some desire, the license terms "are completely absurd in the way they are written." Even taking them "as they are likely intended," Frankel wrote,

entry.title: Digital River Runs Dry
entry.summary: Digital River Runs Dry
entry.content:
Digital River has not paid numerous merchants since midsummer for software and digital products they sold through its MyCommerce platform. "After over 20 years of partnership with Digital River, Traction Software Ltd has been left feeling as though we’ve been 'rug pulled,'" Lee Midgley, managing director of Traction Software, told The Register. "For the past three months, we’ve experienced a complete halt in software sales revenue payments with no support, no direct contact, and only additional terms and conditions designed to delay resolution and extract more money from us."
\n
Astonishingly, Digital River continued to take sales from our loyal customers until we removed them from the order system. It now appears they have no intention of making payments and may be entering a liquidation process under a new CEO who has been involved in similar situations before." The new CEO, Barry Kasoff, was first noted on the e-commerce biz website in August. Kasoff is also listed as the president of Realization Services, "a full-service strategic consulting firm specializing in turnaround management and value enhancement..."

entry.title: Best 4G mobile speeds in Gauteng’s biggest shopping malls
entry.summary: Best 4G mobile speeds in Gauteng’s biggest shopping malls
entry.content:
MyBroadband tested Vodacom, MTN, Cell C, Telkom, and Rain's 4G network performance in Gauteng's biggest malls on October 9-10. The results were mixed:


Brooklyn Mall
Vodacom was the clear winner in Brooklyn Mall, with an average download speed of 121Mbps and an average upload speed of 26Mbps. Telkom scored second place, while Cell C and MTN recorded nearly identical download speeds. MTN recorded double Cell C's upload speed in the mall.


Cell C took first place at Menlyn Park Shopping Centre:


Menlyn
Cell C surprised us in Menlyn with the fastest average download speed of 85Mbps. MTN came in second place with 83Mbps and recorded higher upload speeds of 15Mbps compared to Cell C's 14Mbps.


Vodacom won at Mall of Africa; MTN dominated Fourways Mall; Centurion Mall saw a surprise win for Cell C; Eastgate had another victory for that carrier as well. At Rosebank Mall (and The Zone @ Rosebank), it was a close race between those two, with "Vodacom, Rain, and Telkom all performed poorly." Sandton City also went to Cell C:

entry.title: Efficient High-Resolution Image Synthesis with Linear Diffusion Transformer
entry.summary: Efficient High-Resolution Image Synthesis with Linear Diffusion Transformer
entry.content:
Sana is a text-to-image framework that can efficiently generate images up to 4096 × 4096 resolution. It can synthesize high-resolution, high-quality images with strong text-image alignment at a remarkably fast speed, deployable on laptop GPU.


Core designs include:


  • Deep compression autoencoder: Unlike traditional AEs, which compress images only 8×, we trained an AE that can compress images 32×, effectively reducing the number of latent tokens.
  • Linear DiT: We replace all vanilla attention in DiT with linear attention, which is more efficient at high resolutions without sacrificing quality.
  • Decoder-only text encoder: We replaced T5 with modern decoder-only small LLM as the text encoder and designed complex human instruction with in-context learning to enhance the image-text alignment.
  • Efficient training and sampling: We propose Flow-DPM-Solver to reduce sampling steps, with efficient caption labeling and selection to accelerate convergence.

As a result,


Sana-0.6B is very competitive with modern giant diffusion model (e.g. Flux-12B), being [20 times smaller and] [100+ times faster] in measured throughput. Moreover, Sana-0.6B can be deployed on a 16GB laptop GPU, taking less than one second to generate a [1024 x] [1024] resolution image. Sana enables content creation at low cost.



Comments | View Source

The U.S. Federal Trade Commission proposed a new rule on Tuesday that would require companies to offer consumers an easy way to cancel subscriptions and memberships online, without having to call customer service or navigate through multiple web pages. From a report:


The proposed "click-to-cancel" rule is aimed at preventing so-called subscription traps, where businesses make it easy for customers to sign up but difficult for them to opt out of recurring payments. Such practices can lead consumers into paying for services they no longer want or need, the FTC said in its announcement.

entry.title: Attacking APIs using JSON injection
entry.summary: Attacking APIs using JSON injection
entry.content:
An anonymous reader quotes a blog post:


I wanna tell you a story from not too long ago, where exploiting a JSON injection vulnerability in Samsung devices could trigger an attack chain that ended up with code execution on the device. It seems like the plot from some bad hacker movie. But it wasn't. And it can serve as a lesson on how to abuse APIs who blindly trust the JSON in their payloads far too much...


One of the features of the hub is the ability to connect to smart cameras and process its livestreams, using the RTSP protocol. This code runs in the video-core process, which is running as root. By sending a malicious POST request to the /credentials endpoint, it was possible to modify the credentials used by the hub to connect to remote servers and taint [...] The thing is, many of these devices live in constrained environments. Typically running some sort of embedded Linux to drive code on system-on-chip (SOC) hardware. Which leaves its HTTP servers (and supporting libraries like JSON parsers) somewhat constrained.

entry.title: The early days of peer review: five insights from historic reports
entry.summary: The early days of peer review: five insights from historic reports
entry.content:
The UK Royal Society has more experience of peer review than most publishers, with the practice used by its journals for nearly 200 years. Last month, the society unsealed more than 1,600 historic reports, dating from 1949 to 1954, and added them to its archive. The reports include assessments of high-profile papers. The Royal Society's Philosophical Transactions was the first journal to establish peer review...


Some early referees' reports have news about their holidays or what else they are doing," she adds. What do these and other discussions show us about peer review? "When peer review goes well, it is a system that allows authors to improve the way they communicate their results. It is a unique moment of candid exchange between scientists where anonymity can neutralize the discourse," Ferlier suggests.


Nature rummaged through the archive for insights into the evolution of peer review:

entry.title: All software in EU under product liability from 2026
entry.summary: All software in EU under product liability from 2026
entry.content:
The European Union has adopted a directive to update its civil liability law, which will extend product liability rules to software and digital manufacturing files starting in 2026. From a report:


The new law extends the definition of "product" to digital manufacturing files and software. Also online platforms can be held liable for a defective product sold on their platform just like any other economic operators if they act like one. [...] The directive will enter into force on the twentieth day following that of its publication in the Official Journal of the European Union. entry.title: Amazon Finally Has a Color Kindle
entry.summary: Amazon Finally Has a Color Kindle
entry.content:
Amazon is launching the Kindle Colorsoft Signature Edition, a color version of its e-reader, for $279.99 on October 30th. The Verge reports:


For years, Kindle users have asked Amazon to make a color version of its e-reader. Now, the company is finally delivering: it's launching the new Kindle Colorsoft Signature Edition, a device that has a lot in common with the new Paperwhite, except instead of black and white it's color all over...


The Colorsoft is based on E Ink's Kaleido technology but uses an entirely new display stack for Kindles, all the way back to a newly designed oxide backplane that makes it easier for E Ink panel's tiny bits of ink to move around quickly... All that display tech [...] allowed Amazon to introduce color without adding page-turn latency, lowering the device's resolution, or hurting contrast on the display.

entry.title: Solving the Maker-Taker problem
entry.summary: Solving the Maker-Taker problem
entry.content:
An anonymous reader shared this summary from Dries Buytaert, founder and project lead of the open-source content management system Drupal:


Recently, a public dispute has emerged between WordPress co-founder Matt Mullenweg and hosting company WP Engine. Matt has accused WP Engine of misleading users through its branding and profiting from WordPress without adequately contributing back to the project.


Although this post was prompted by the controversy between Automattic and WP Engine, it is not about them. I don't have insight into their respective contributions to WordPress, and I'm not here to judge. I've made an effort to keep this post as neutral as possible.


Buytaert argues that both companies are "Makers" who contribute significantly to open source software development, while others in their ecosystem are "Takers," who profit off those efforts without giving back enough in return. He calls for more equitable systems across all open-source projects — including a contribution credit system similar to Drupal's at other open-source organizations like Wordpress:


Addressing the Maker-Taker challenge is essential for the long-term sustainability of open source projects. Drupal's approach may provide a constructive solution not just for WordPress, but for other communities facing similar issues.


By transparently rewarding contributions and fostering collaboration, we can build healthier open source ecosystems. A credit system can help make open source more sustainable and fair, driving growth, competitiveness, and potentially creating thousands of new open source businesses.



Comments | View Source

entry.title: Home Affairs crackdown in South Africa
entry.summary: Home Affairs crackdown in South Africa
entry.content:
The Department of Home Affairs (DHA) is cracking down on corruption within its ranks and finalised 31 disciplinary cases between July and September 2024, some of which resulted in criminal prosecution and dismissal. One such individual, Mogale Raseone, is set to have his trial start on 6 November. He is facing charges of fraud after being dismissed from the DHA in 2023 for manipulating department systems to fraudulently administer immigration for foreign nationals.


In a statement, the department said the crackdown reflects its commitment to eradicating maladministration. It notes that officials faced charges for violating the Citizen and Immigration Acts and irregularly recruiting new staff, with eight cases coming out of the Free State and six out of KwaZulu-Natal. "We have zero tolerance for unethical conduct or corruption," said DHA Minister Leon Schreiber. "As our accelerated action against errant conduct demonstrates, officials who fail to heed this message will soon find themselves out of Home Affairs and on their way to prison."


Another official, Dora Ncube, is awaiting her day in court. The suspended Border Management Authority official was arrested
for allegedly trying to smuggle six foreign nationals into South Africa in Beitbridge.

entry.title: Amazon refreshes its monochrome Kindle lineup, including a bigger Paperwhite
entry.summary: Amazon refreshes its monochrome Kindle lineup, including a bigger Paperwhite
entry.content:
Amazon is refreshing its entire Kindle e-reader lineup today, including a major refresh to the pen-centric Kindle Scribe and a screen-size bump for the mainstream Kindle Paperwhite. The company also added its first color e-reader, called the Kindle Colorsoft. From a report:


Going from most to least significant: The new Kindle Scribe's upgrades are mostly meant to make it a more paper-like writing experience. It has a new textured screen coating, a white screen bezel that blends into the screen (we've also seen this deployed in tablets like the reMarkable Paper Pro), and a tweaked Premium Pen accessory with "a new soft-tipped eraser" that feels more like an actual pencil eraser. Other improvements are being implemented in software, not hardware. A new notetaking feature called Active Canvas allows you to draw in the margins of e-books, making text reflow around your notes --previously, handwritten notes opened a separate pop-up, just like typed notes. A future software update will let you hide and show those notes.


The new Kindle Scribe begins shipping on December 4 and starts at $399.99 — which is heftier than previous models but does include Amazon's Premium Pen accessory by default.


The article continues with details about other devices:

entry.title: Douglas Hofstadter on Lisp (1983)
entry.summary: Douglas Hofstadter on Lisp (1983)
entry.content:
Douglas Hofstadter's 1983 introduction to Lisp, reprinted in his book Metamagical Themas, is a charming and idiosyncratic tour of the programming language that has been used for decades in artificial intelligence research. From the article:


In previous columns I have written quite often about the field of artificial intelligence -- the search for ways to program computers so that they might come to behave with flexibility, common sense, insight, creativity, self awareness, humor, and so on. The quest for AI started in earnest over two decades ago... One thing that is nearly unanimous is the choice of programming language. Most AI research efforts are carried out in a language called "Lisp". (The name is not quite an acronym; it stands for "list processing".)

The advisory group aims to unite industry leaders to shape the future of x86 and foster developer innovation through a more unified set of instructions and architectural interfaces. This initiative will enhance compatibility, predictability and consistency across x86 product offerings. To achieve this, the group will solicit technical input from the x86 hardware and software communities on essential functions and features. Collaboration will facilitate the creation of consistent and compatible implementations of key x86 architectural features and programming models, extending across all sectors -- including data centers, cloud, client, edge [and] embedded devices -- ultimately delivering downstream benefits to customers.

entry.title: Beware new WhatsApp scam in South Africa
entry.summary: Beware new WhatsApp scam in South Africa
entry.content:
An anonymous reader quotes a report from MyBroadband:


A MyBroadband reader working as a rental agent contacted us after experiencing a scam that involved an attacker compromising communications between them and a client, placing both at risk of being defrauded. Their story provides insight into how attackers are becoming increasingly sophisticated in targeting their victims and stealing millions from unsuspecting people trying to do business with each other. In this case, the attack was a fairly typical attempt to intercept and divert funds in a property transaction -- but with a WhatsApp twist. The agent told MyBroadband they had arranged a rental viewing with a client, only to discover they had been communicating with a middleman instead of directly with each other as they thought.


While viewing the property, the client mentioned that the agent had said the owner was willing to negotiate on the price. This came as a shock to the agent, who could not recall the specific discussion. However, the client showed them the WhatsApp conversation, which indicated that they had indeed discussed [...] Upon closer inspection, [the] agent realised that it was not their contact number [...]. It was also soon realised that [the] agent had a different name to what [the] client had been told on WhatsApp. The agent then checked their WhatsApp conversation with [the] client,* which again had a different contact number than the one [the] client used.** This indicates that [...+]


The South African Banking Risk Information Centre (Sabric) provides several indications that your email address might have been compromised, including:


  • Complaints about spam being sent from your email address
  • Emails not being received
  • Missing emails
  • Receiving large numbers of undeliverable or bounce messages for emails you did not send
  • Not being able to log into your email account
  • Seeing unknown emails in your Sent Items folder

To further protect yourself from falling for [...+] scam, you should verify bank account details through multiple official channels. This can include making phone calls or sending messages to numbers and email addresses listed on company websites or social media pages.



Comments | View Source

entry.title: Traveling with Apple Vision Pro
entry.summary: Traveling with Apple Vision Pro
entry.content:
The Vision Pro has quickly become an essential item that I take onto every flight. It’s a fantastic device to travel with—Be it by train or by plane, it offers an unparalleled opportunity to selectively tune out your environment and sink into an engaging activity like watching a movie or just working on your laptop. In this blog post, I’ll outline what I’ve learned about the Vision Pro while traveling, explain some of the functionality, shine light onto its drawbacks, as well as assess how it fares against solutions like a phone or a laptop.


For context, most of the traveling where I’ve brought my Vision Pro along has been on airplanes, but this applies to traveling by train as well.


Packing / Travel Setup


First and foremost, space in my suitcase or backpack while traveling is the most valuable commodity. Whenever I'm packing for a trip,


anything that adds unnecessary bulk to my setup is immediately discarded. For that reason, I highly recommend that you do NOT purchase


the behemoth of the $200 Vision Pro "travel case" from Apple. It's unnecessarily massive and doesn't fit into ANYTHING. Avoid it at all costs unless you absolutely need a crazy amount of protection from the elements (but at that point,


might as well buy a Pelican case!).


My travel setup is super simple and minimal. To protect the front glass, I use the "Vision Pro Cover" that comes by default with


the headset and on the inside, I use this affordable generic VR lens protector cover to prevent anything from scratching [...]. With this setup, I've not scratched or damaged


the headset itself at all over [the] 5-10 flights I've taken it on.**


User Experience


At airport security line, typically pull out my laptop and [Apple's] Vision Pro from my backpack. Thankfully, seems like [it doesn't look suspicious](/2024/10/08/traveling-with-apple-vision-pro/#airport-security-line) at all while being x-rayed as I've not been questioned about it yet. The Vision Pro's 6DoF tracking system is built on a combination of IMU's + SLAM cameras (same as any other VR headsets).


Unlike other VR headsets, however, it has native "[Travel Mode]"(https://azadux.blog/2024/10/08/traveling-with-apple-vision-pro/#travel-mode) which accounts for using one in moving vehicles leading to massive drift & tracking issues. As soon as it's put on when flying through turbulence it'll suggest turning Travel Mode ON via actionable notification; once activated it'll ignore IMU data entirely so horizon will be determined purely based upon orientation & rotation of user's head instead — if their head tilts downwards then virtual apps/windows will tilt downwards too until they re-initialize manually after covering up lenses with hands briefly so cameras can lock back onto surroundings again without needing them visible anymore first before doing so themselves afterwards afterward...


While wearing AirPods Pros are great because they offer top-of-the-line active noise cancellation but also adaptive/transparency modes allowing selective hearing depending upon situation...


[...]


One caveat: during meals requiring eyesight coordination (like using fork picking food off plate):


as soon user looks down towards food tracking often gets lost causing movie stop playing until looking forward again re-initializes tracking... Also field view more horizontal than vertical making eating challenging requiring fully tilting one's neck downward see what's happening below oneself rather than simply glancing sideways across table surface level instead! So usually remove headset eat meal return back afterwards later continue watching film uninterruptedly thereafter instead!**


Once started becoming more affordable foresee regular travelers buying them just have amazing in-flight entertainment systems since truly incredible experience altogether!



Comments | View Source

entry.title: FTC Announces "Click-to-Cancel" Rule Making It Easier to Cancel Subscriptions
entry.summary: FTC Announces "Click-to-Cancel" Rule Making It Easier to Cancel Subscriptions
entry.content:
The Federal Trade Commission today announced a final "click-to-cancel" rule that will require sellers to make it as easy for consumers to cancel their enrollment as it was to sign up. Most of the final rule's provisions will go into effect 180 days after it is published in the Federal Register.


"Too often, businesses make people jump through endless hoops just to cancel a subscription," said Commission Chair Lina M. Khan. "The FTC's rule will end these tricks and traps, saving Americans time and money. Nobody should be stuck paying for a service they no longer want."


The Commission's updated rule will apply to almost all negative option programs in any media. The rule also will prohibit sellers from misrepresenting any material facts while using negative option marketing; require sellers to provide important information before obtaining consumers' billing information and charging them; and require sellers to get consumers' informed consent to the negative option features before charging them.



Comments | View Source

The investment is part of Amazon's broader push into nuclear energy, which it sees as key to powering its data centres and achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2040. In September, Amazon ordered two X-Energy reactors for an undisclosed location in North America.


[...] Small modular reactors are seen as safer than traditional large-scale plants because they can be built off-site, transported and installed at their final destination. They also use less water than conventional designs.

entry.title: Discord Rejects Role as 'Anti-Piracy' Partner; will no longer respond to DMCAs
entry.summary: Discord Rejects Role as 'Anti-Piracy' Partner; will no longer respond to DMCAs
entry.content:
Korean game publisher Nexon is using the U.S. legal system to address online copyright infringement. The company obtained a DMCA subpoena that requires Discord to hand over the personal details of suspected pirates. While Discord has shared information in the past, it doesn't plan to cooperate any longer, refusing to play the role of 'anti-piracy police'. From a report:


Under U.S. law, rightsholders have an option to identify alleged copyright infringers, without directly having to file a lawsuit. Instead, they can request a DMCA subpoena. These documents are typically signed by a court clerk and don't require any judicial oversight. Specifically, they allow rightsholders to obtain the personal details of anonymous alleged infringers through third-party service providers.


Discord's attorney wrote in July that "acting as your copyright assertion partner is not one of them."


This strongly-worded letter didn't have the desired result, however. Instead of backing off, Nexon doubled down, filing (PDF) a motion to compel at a Texas federal court late last week.



Comments | View Source

entry.summary: Talos Linux: API driven, Kubernetes operating system
entry.content:
Talos Linux is a minimal, immutable operating system designed specifically for Kubernetes. It can run on cloud platforms, bare metal, and virtualization environments. All management of the OS is done via an API -- no SSH or console access allowed.

entry.title: The Failure of the GPL (2009)
entry.summary: The Failure of the GPL (2009)
entry.content:
David Chisnall casts a critical eye over the GNU General Public License (GPL), arguing that it has done more harm than good for the Free Software movement. He recounts how, in 1985, the Free Software Foundation was formed to promote software freedom as defined by four freedoms:


The freedom to run the program, for any purpose;
The freedom to study how the program works and adapt it to your needs;
The freedom to redistribute copies so you can help your neighbor;
The freedom to improve the program and release your improvements (and modified versions in general) to the public so that whole community benefits.


Chisnall notes that one of their tools is "the GNU General Public License (GPL)." But looking back he asks: "has [the GPL] been a help or a hindrance? And will it continue to be a help or hindrance in future?"


He begins with an example of what he sees as its success — but also its failure:


In 1985, NeXT purchased rights Objective-C...The C compiler at time was GCC, which was released under GPL. To avoid restrictions this code, NeXT provided its front end as library that end users would link against GCC...This little legal maneuver didn't work however, so NeXT was forced release code. Remember that an Objective-C implementation is two parts: compiler runtime library...NeXT only required release its compiler code, not runtime library...


"Rather than admit they had worthless bit of code," writes Chisnall, "GNU Project wrote own Objective-C runtime — and this where things really started getting interesting." This led Apple developers working on GCC adding features like SIMD support while simultaneously falling behind on supporting new features from GNU's branch.


"The story doesn't quite end there," adds Chisnall. More recently, Apple wanted integrate compiler more closely with IDE. One nice things about Visual Studio is uses same parser semantic analyzer syntax highlighting error reporting as does for code generation allowing much better feedback than get from editors completely separate two. Unfortunately for Apple, GPL required either making XCode open source rewriting GCC..."


"Fortunately," says Chisnall, "Apple didn't have start from scratch..."


But he argues this shows both sides of his argument:


First we learn you don't necessarily get good results forcing people do things. NeXT Objective-C code contributed GCC\n
reluctantly, and never well maintained....end result better everyone.[...] Second thing remember sometimes having someone else's isn't actually good thing....If team had done this they probably would designed support multiple runtime libraries start ended up something lot more maintainable end.



Comments | View Source

Customers now demand swift, reliable delivery options, and companies that can't provide trusted courier services risk losing sales and falling behind competitors who can meet these rising expectations with speed and convenience.


As South Africa's trusted choice for convenient, reliable, and affordable parcel deliveries,


PAXI has been transforming the way everyday consumers send and receive packages. For businesses, their easy deliveries and returns solutions have been a game changer, allowing companies to effortlessly reach their customers anywhere in the country by simply using any of PAXI's network of over 2,800 PAXI counterpoints nationwide. This means companies can increase their revenue by having the ability to reach customers in remote areas, nationwide.


PAXI's seamless business-to-door delivery offering goes one step further by giving businesses even more delivery options for their customers to choose from, enhancing convenience and efficiency. This offering is tailored for companies that need to get their goods directly to the door of their clients or third parties quickly and efficiently...

entry.title: Digital River runs dry, hasn't paid developers for sales since July
entry.summary: Digital River runs dry, hasn't paid developers for sales since July
entry.content:
Digital River has not paid numerous merchants since midsummer for software and digital products they sold through its MyCommerce platform. "After over 20 years of partnership with Digital River, Traction Software Ltd has been left feeling as though we've been 'rug pulled,'" Lee Midgley, managing director of Traction Software, told The Register. "For the past three months, we've experienced a complete halt in software sales revenue payments with no support, no direct contact, and only additional terms and conditions designed to delay resolution and extract more money from us." [...] The privately-owned, Minnesota-based business appears to have laid off a significant number of employees, presumably the result of what its UK subsidiary describes as cost reduction initiatives implemented in late 2022. Digital River, Inc, owned by parent New York-based Danube Private Holdings II, LLC, has several subsidiaries including Digital River GmbH, Digital River Ireland Ltd, and Digital River UK Limited. The company did not respond to a request for comment.

entry.title: My solar-powered and self-hosted website
entry.summary: My solar-powered and self-hosted website
entry.content:
Long-time Slashdot reader Dries Buytaert has been experimenting with a solar-powered, self-hosted website running on a Raspberry Pi. The site is powered entirely by a solar panel and battery on his roof deck in Boston. He writes:


By visiting https://solar.dri.es, you can dive into all the technical details and lessons learned -- from hardware setup to networking configuration and custom monitoring. As the content on this solar-powered site is likely to evolve or might even disappear over time, I've included the full article below (with minor edits) to ensure that this information is preserved.


He explains how he set it up — including using an RS485 CAN HAT module for real-time data collection — then discusses its energy use, cost savings, and environmental impact:


The tiny Raspberry Pi Zero 2 W at the heart of this project uses just 1 Watt on average. This translates to 0.024 kWh daily (1W * 24h / 1000 = 0.024 kWh) and approximately 9 kWh annually (0.024 kWh * 365 days = 8.76 kWh). The cost savings? Looking at our last electricity bill, we pay an average of $0.325 per kWh in Boston... Saving 9 kWh per year reduces CO2 emissions by roughly 4 kg, which is about the same as driving 16 kilometers (10 miles) by car.



Comments | View Source

entry.title: Intel spends more on R&D than Nvidia and AMD combined
entry.summary: Intel spends more on R&D than Nvidia and AMD combined
entry.content:
Intel spent over $16.5 billion on research and development in 2023, more than AMD and Nvidia combined, according to Tom's Hardware. But while Intel is still the biggest R&D spender among semiconductor companies, it continues to lag behind them in market capitalization:


[...] Apple spent around $27 billion or $29.915 billion on R&D in 2023, which is more than AMD, Nvidia, and Qualcomm combined.


Qualcomm is another high spender on R&D. The company invests in system-on-chips for client devices like smartphones and PCs, RF technologies, and fundamental research for next-generation radio technologies (6G, 7G, etc.). Perhaps the most interesting part about Qualcomm is that among all the high-tech companies mentioned in this news story; it is the only one with a working 5G modem.

Korean game publisher Nexon is using the U.S. legal system to address online copyright infringement. The company obtained a DMCA subpoena that requires Discord to hand over the personal details of suspected pirates. While Discord has shared information in the past, it doesn't plan to cooperate any longer, refusing to play the role of 'anti-piracy police' (TorrentFreak).
\


Under U.S. law, rightsholders have an option to identify alleged copyright infringers, without directly having to file a lawsuit. Instead, they can request a DMCA subpoena. These documents are typically signed by a court clerk and don't require any judicial oversight... When Nexon obtained a DMCA subpoena last October, Discord initially objected, deeming it "overbroad and unduly burdensome." After the parties got together, an agreement was reached to confidentially disclose basic subscriber information related to 64 Discord User IDs.
\


Discord was clearly hesitant to cooperate but, faced with a motion to compel, it eventually chose to do so.... However, going forward, the company doesn't intend [...] In July,


Discord sent a letter [to Nexon], informing the game company that it has no intention of cooperating with the latest request, describing it as improper.

entry.title: Tesla needs to come clean about HW3 before the word 'fraud' comes out
entry.summary: Tesla needs to come clean about HW3 before the word 'fraud' comes out
entry.content:
The walls are closing on Tesla's claim that millions of its vehicles with Hardware 3 (HW3) computers will be capable of unsupervised self-driving. [Electrek](/~article/2024/10/15/tesla-needs-to-come-clean-about-hw3-before-the-word-fraud-comes-out/) reports:


Making a mistake is not a fraud. If Tesla really thought that it could deliver unsupervised self-driving to vehicles equipped with HW3 and, at one point, it figured out that it couldn't, it's not fraud even though it used that as a selling point for millions of vehicles for years. However, the moment Tesla figures out that it can't, it needs to stop selling its Full Self-Driving package to HW3 vehicle owners and come clean to owners about what their vehicle will and will not be able to do, like a robotaxi service.

entry.title: One possible housing crisis solution? Public housing for all income levels
entry.summary: One possible housing crisis solution? Public housing for all income levels
entry.content:
Montgomery County, Maryland has created a $100 million revolving fund that allows it to develop and finance its own housing projects. NPR reports:


It recently broke ground on Hillandale Gateway: 463 new mixed-income apartments that will be majority owned by Maryland's Montgomery County. It's public housing. Although this is a far different model than traditional, federally funded housing for only the very poor...


Montgomery County is a wealthy community, and it's long focused on housing for lower-earning families. Still, it hasn't built nearly enough to keep up with demand, and the gap is growing. So a few years ago, it took an unusual step: It created a $100 million revolving fund to dramatically ramp up construction... The public agency owns the controlling stake in these apartments.

entry.title: Starlink roaming cutoff survivors
entry.summary: Starlink roaming cutoff survivors
entry.content:
Many Starlink users in South Africa have continued to use the SpaceX-run service after it implemented a 60-day continuous roaming use rule, which has made accessing the service more cumbersome and expensive. In addition, one specialist importer has seen a surge in sales of Starlink kits in recent weeks, which it attributed to positive political movements regarding the service's approval in South Africa. These developments show there is strong demand for low-earth-orbit satellite Internet service in South Africa, despite the country's communications regulator deeming it illegal.


Starlink's roaming service has allowed people who managed to import a kit from an officially supported country by themselves or via a specialised unofficial importer to use its fast and uncapped Internet for nearly two years. While it cannot compete with cost-effective broadband solutions available in highly populated areas, like fibre, fixed-5G, and fixed-LTE, Starlink is unmatched in connectivity-deprived rural areas. Aside from the Starlink kit, users in South Africa only need a power source and a largely-unobstructed view of the sky in a southerly direction.


MyBroadband's hands-on tests have shown the service can support fibre-like speeds and connection stability that outperforms older satellite Internet. While Starlink has been illegal in South Africa since late 2022 due to not having required operating licences, [...]

The archive.org home page points users to the now-functional Wayback Machine but notes that other Internet Archive services are temporarily offline. From a report:


Kahle said it was "safe to resume" the Wayback Machine's operations, but that it "might need further maintenance, in which case it will be suspended again." The Wayback Machine's "Save Page Now" feature that lets users capture a webpage manually is currently unavailable. The related openlibrary.org book-preservation website was still offline today.

entry.title: Israel's bulky pager fooled Hezbollah
entry.summary: Israel's bulky pager fooled Hezbollah
entry.content:
An anonymous reader quotes a report from Reuters:


The batteries inside the weaponised pagers that arrived in Lebanon at the start of the year, part of an Israeli plot to decimate Hezbollah, had powerfully deceptive features and an Achilles' heel. The agents who built the pagers designed a battery that concealed a small but potent charge of plastic explosive and a novel detonator that was invisible to X-ray, according to a Lebanese source with first-hand knowledge of the pagers, and teardown photos of the battery pack seen by Reuters. To overcome the weakness -- the absence of a plausible backstory for
[the] bulky new product -- they created fake online stores, pages and posts that could deceive Hezbollah due diligence, a Reuters review of web archives shows.

entry.title: Police want the password to your phone
entry.summary: Police want the password to your phone
entry.content:
Police should never be allowed past your phone's lock screen without a warrant and specific proof of incriminating evidence, argues Lee Duna at programming.dev. "The police have the right to search your home, but they don't have the right to search through every single piece of paper in that home," he writes. "They need a warrant for that." From his article:


The same principle applies to phones. Your phone is an extension of yourself; it contains all sorts of private data. If you were arrested, the police could not just take your phone and start scrolling through it looking for something incriminating -- they'd need a warrant first.


Duna argues that this principle has been upheld by courts in various countries around the world, including Canada, Australia, New Zealand and Germany. In 2014 U.S. Supreme Court Justice John Roberts wrote: "Our answer to the question of whether law enforcement officers may conduct a warrantless search of cell phones seized incident to arrest is no."

entry.title: Commission concludes that X should not be designated under the DMA
entry.summary: Commission concludes that X should not be designated under the DMA
entry.content:
The European Commission has concluded that the online social networking service of X (formerly Twitter) should not be designated as a core platform service under the Digital Markets Act (DMA). From a report:


Today's decision comes after an in-depth market investigation launched on 13 May 2024 following the notification by X of its status of potential gatekeeper. Together with the notification, X also submitted rebuttal arguments, explaining why its online social networking service should not, in its view, qualify as an important gateway between businesses and consumers, even if X is deemed to meet the quantitative thresholds set out in the DMA. Following a thorough assessment of all arguments, including input by relevant stakeholders, and after consulting the Digital Markets Advisory Committee, the Commission concluded that X does indeed not qualify as a gatekeeper in relation to its online social networking service, given that the investigation revealed that X is not an important gateway for business users to reach end users.

entry.title: Floss/fund: $1M per year for free and open source projects
entry.summary: Floss/fund: $1M per year for free and open source projects
entry.content:
Zerodha, an Indian financial services company, has launched a fund called FLOSS/fund to provide $1 million per year in financial assistance to free and open source software (FOSS) projects globally. From a report:


This has been in the works for some time at Zerodha, where we have been developing financial technology products and services built on an ever-growing FOSS stack. Without the high-quality FOSS projects that we have freely downloaded and used to build our organisation, products, and services, we would not exist as we do today -- free as in both cost and freedom. A significant portion of our success and growth is owed to FOSS...


And yet, funding and financial sustainability, the lack thereof really, has been an increasingly hot topic over the last many years. Well, at least since cloud companies began making massive profits directly repackaging FOSS projects built by hobbyists and communities. The rise of the "open core" model and the unfortunate license changes in many good open projects recently, are clear signs of this growing turmoil.

entry.title: Can't trust any VPN these days
entry.summary: Can't trust any VPN these days
entry.content:
An anonymous reader shared a blog post:


On October 9th 2024, Discord was banned in Turkey due to various criminal allegations. This was an ongoing issue and Discord apparently refused to share user data (IP addresses and content) thus the government decided to block the whole thing altogether...


Today I'm here to share what I have learned while trying to... you know. Find a way to use Discord again. Surprisingly, this ban ended up being a positive experience for me.


Orhun writes about how he discovered his VPN wasn't working as intended when he tried using it after returning home from an airport trip on that fateful day:


The most mind-boggling part of the problem for me was that I was able to use Discord via OpenVPN on my phone but not on my computer. Whenever I try to launch the desktop app, it gets stuck at the loading screen with the error message I shared above. To limit the scope of the problem, I also tried the website app directly, which resulted in the certificate error. How does Discord know that I'm still in Turkey!?


He eventually figured out "I was using my ISP's DNS instead of my VPN's DNS..." He then had to install some packages and add lines into his OpenVPN configuration file before finally getting everything back up and running:


# install Openresolv for managing DNS settings


pacman -S openresolv

# install the script for updating DNS with OpenVPN (use your favorite AUR helper)


paru -S openvpn-update-resolv-conf-git

Then add [...]


script-security 2 # Allow script execution


up /etc/openvpn/update-resolv-conf


down /etc/openvpn/update-resolv-conf


And run [...]


openvpn --config $HOME/.openvpn/client.ovpn


Boom, no more leaks! It goes through Frankfurt as expected! And I can use Discord again!



Comments | View Source

entry.title: South African students uncover massive grant fraud
entry.summary: South African students uncover massive grant fraud
entry.content:
Two first-year computer science students at Stellenbosch University, Joel Cedras and Veer Gosai, have uncovered massive fraud in the Social Relief of Distress (SRD) grant administered by the South African Social Security Agency (SASSA). After the pair discovered that their and their friends' R370 grants were being stolen, they investigated further and found a bank account registered in Cedras' name that had been receiving the grant every month. As first reported on GroundUp, fraudsters use unsuspecting citizens' identity numbers to apply for the SRD grant and receive the funds in bank accounts they have set up using the same ID numbers.


"We had to call some banks, and eventually we found a bank account with my name, and they were receiving my R370 grant every month," Cedras told Heart FM.


However, the issue extends far beyond a group of university students.


To investigate further, Cedras and Gosai queried SASSA's application programming interface (API) for February 2005 at a rate of 700 records per minute. This was already a problem, as it should not be possible to query the agency's database at such speeds. The pair found that nearly 75,000 SRD grant applications were made for people born in February 2005. There were around 82,100 births that month, working out to an application rate of about 91%. "That's a very high amount that over 90% of people born in that month had an active Sassa application," sad Gosai.


This indicates that not only are fraudulent applications being submitted to SASSA but many are also likely succeeding. The students also conducted an on-campus survey of 60 other students they knew. Of the 60 respondents,


58 had active SRD grant applications


of which only two said they had applied for the grant themselves.


Speaking to Heart FM,


SASSA grant admission head Brenton van Vrede admitted


that the organisation's grants system had been breached.


"We do unfortunately have quite a lot of these cases," said Van Vrede. "Some of the criminals have been apprehended. My personal view though is that it is at a very low level... We do think there's a bigger operation behind this." He added [...]


Van Vrede explained that many South Africans may find that an active application is already pending under their ID number when they attempt to apply for
the SRD grant.


"In such an instance, clients do need to then call our call centre, and then we have [...] facial biometric system
to verify true person behind ID number."


Cedras and Gosai believe there is no straightforward solution to [...] crisis due scale crisis.** The pair said SASSA should re-verify every
grant application request additional details do so.** They also recommend organization reimplement its system from scratch.**


However, note would leave many recipients out pocket.* Moreover, Cedras Gosai believe SASSA’s focus biometric verification undermines purpose SRD
grant designed accessible even people using devices lowest specifications.* The pair demanding answers from SASSA wants organization disclose cause scale crisis well who developed maintains SASSA SRD system what cost.*



Comments | View Source

entry.title: Sustainable Building Effort Reaches New Heights With Wooden Skyscrapers
entry.summary: Sustainable Building Effort Reaches New Heights With Wooden Skyscrapers
entry.content:
Long-time Slashdot reader jones_supa shares a report:


At the University of Toronto, just across the street from the football stadium, workers are putting up a 14-story building with space for classrooms and faculty offices. What's unusual is how they're building it -- by bolting together giant beams, columns and panels made of manufactured slabs of wood. As each wood element is delivered by flatbed, a tall crane lifts it into place and holds it in position while workers attach it with metal connectors. In its half-finished state, the building resembles flat-pack furniture in the process of being assembled.


The tower uses a new technology called mass timber. In this kind of construction, massive, manufactured wood elements that can extend more than half the length of a football field replace steel beams and concrete...


Today, the tallest mass timber building is the 25-story Ascent skyscraper in Milwaukee, completed in 2022. As of that year, there were 84 mass timber buildings eight stories or higher either built or under construction worldwide, with another 55 proposed. Seventy percent of the existing and future buildings were in Europe, about 20 percent in North America and [...] According to estimates from researchers at Central European University,


Ürge-Vorsatz says mass timber could be an important part [in combating climate change]. "If you use bio-based material, we have a double win," Ürge-Vorsatz says...

entry.title: E.W. Dijkstra Archive: On the cruelty of really teaching computing science (EWD 1036)
entry.summary: E.W. Dijkstra Archive: On the cruelty of really teaching computing science (EWD 1036)
entry.content:
Long-time Slashdot reader E.W. Dijkstra Archive shares a transcription of an 1988 talk by the late computer scientist Edsger W. Dijkstra, who argued that "automatic computers represent a radical novelty" and that only by identifying them as such can we identify all the nonsense, misconceptions and mythology surrounding them." The second radical novelty is that the automatic computer is our first large-scale digital device," he added.


It is possible, and even tempting, to view a program as an abstract mechanism, as a device of some sort. To do so, however, is highly dangerous: the analogy is too shallow because a program is, as a mechanism, totally different from all the familiar analogue devices we grew up with... In the discrete world of computing there is no meaningful metric in which "small" changes and "small" effects go hand in hand....


This second radical novelty shares the usual fate of all radical novelties: it is denied because its truth would be too discomforting... I have no idea what this specific denial and disbelief costs the United States but a million dollars a day seems like modest guess...



Comments | View Source

entry.title: Mullvad: macOS sometimes leaks traffic after system updates
entry.summary: Mullvad: macOS sometimes leaks traffic after system updates
entry.content:
Mullvad VPN has discovered a traffic leak on macOS after system updates, which can be resolved by rebooting the machine. From a report:


In this scenario the macOS firewall does not seem to function correctly and is disregarding firewall rules. Most traffic will still go inside the VPN tunnel since the routing table specifies that it should. Unfortunately apps are not required to respect the routing table and can send traffic outside the tunnel if they try to. Some examples of apps that do this are Apple's own apps and services since macOS 14.6, up until a recent 15.1 beta.


Mullvad says it's currently investigating further, but in the meantime users can check whether they're affected with some terminal commands (detailed instructions at their blog).



Comments | View Source

This has been in the works for some time at Zerodha[↗], where we have been developing financial technology products and services built on an ever-growing FOSS stack. Without the high-quality FOSS projects that we have freely downloaded and used to build our organisation, products, and services, we would not exist as we do today -- free as in both cost and freedom. The fund aims "to exercise goodwill," said Kailash Nadh (CTO @ Zerodha). "It makes perfect logical sense for a business that relies on FOSS...to support it."

Since early 2023, the world has seen a steep rise in temperatures that scientists are struggling to explain. Our contributor Elizabeth Kolbert talked with Gavin Schmidt, NASA's top climate scientist, about possible causes of the warming and why experts cannot account for the heat.


About 18 months ago, climate scientists began to notice something strange. In March of 2023, global sea surface temperatures started to rise. In a warming world, the seas would be expected to grow hotter, but the rise -- which came at a time when the Pacific Ocean was in the neutral phase of the weather pattern known as the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) -- was unusually steep. In April 2023, sea surface temperatures set a new record. They did so again in May...

entry.title: Capitec blocks payments to cryptocurrency exchanges
entry.summary: Capitec blocks payments to cryptocurrency exchanges
entry.content:
Capitec has blocked EFT and immediate payments to cryptocurrency exchanges from its smartphone app and business web interface. The issue was first highlighted by Shiftly co-founder and CEO Carel de Villiers. When MyBroadband asked Capitec about the change, the bank said it was an anti-fraud measure.


"Capitec is committed to protecting our clients from fraud, which is why we made the decision to block EFT and immediate real-time clearing payments to crypto exchanges on our app and business web interface," a spokesperson said. "We recognise the increasing interest in cryptocurrencies and encourage users to utilise Capitec Pay as a secure alternative for transactions." Capitec said it was actively working with crypto exchanges that have not yet integrated Capitec Pay to expedite this process.


Ensuring the safety and security of our clients' financial transactions remains our top priority," it said. This change came after Capitec announced that its app now communicates with its Fraud Center in real-time. It said the app will warn customers and block payments in real time if any beneficiaries have reported or confirmed fraud against them. For example, even brand new bank accounts created at any institution will be blocked for all Capitec clients if there is confirmed fraud reported against it. According to Capitec, it is the first bank to do real-time and on-the-wire interception and blocking of suspicious payments [...].

entry.title: First Section of Euclid Space Telescope's Map of the Universe Revealed
entry.summary: First Section of Euclid Space Telescope's Map of the Universe Revealed
entry.content:
The first chunk of what will be the largest 3D map of the universe ever made has been revealed, putting 14 million galaxies -- not to mention tens of millions of stars in our own Milky Way -- on show in incredible detail. The Euclid mission, launched in 2023 and run by the European Space Agency (Esa) with contributions from Nasa, sent its first snapshots in November of that year and in May 2024. From a report:


The goal of Euclid is to enable the creation of a 3D map in time and space of the universe, in an attempt to elucidate its evolution and, as a result, shed light on the mysterious phenomena of dark energy and dark matter that together make up 95% of the universe.


The newly released data is a mosaic of 208 gigapixels and covers [1%](/science/exploration/universe/cosmic-mystery-dark-energy-dark-matter)* [of](/science/exploration/universe/cosmic-mystery-dark-energy-dark-matter). The completed map is expected to involve six years' worth observations and will take in a third [of](/science/exploration/universe/cosmic-mystery-dark-energy-dark-matter) [the](/science/exploration/universe/cosmic-mystery-dark-energy-dark-matter) sky, with observations expected to capture billions [of](/science/exploration/universe/cosmic-mystery-dark-energy-dark-matter) galaxies out to (10bn light years.)

entry.title: Safer with Google: Advancing Memory Safety
entry.summary: Safer with Google: Advancing Memory Safety
entry.content:
Google's security team has detailed its ongoing efforts to improve memory safety in the software it uses and produces, including a two-pronged strategy that involves migrating existing codebases to memory-safe languages like Rust, while also hardening legacy C++ code. From a report:


Error-prone interactions between software and memory are widely understood to create safety issues in software. It is estimated that about 70% of severe vulnerabilities in memory-unsafe codebases are due to memory safety bugs. Malicious actors exploit these vulnerabilities and continue to create real-world harm. In 2023, Google's threat intelligence teams conducted an industry-wide study and observed a close to all-time high number of vulnerabilities exploited in the wild. Our internal analysis estimates that 75% of CVEs used in zero-day exploits are memory safety vulnerabilities...


This post builds upon our previously reported Perspective on Memory Safety, and introduces our strategic approach to memory safety.

entry.title: Smartphone import warning in South Africa
entry.summary: Smartphone import warning in South Africa
entry.content:
South Africans importing smartphones instead of buying locally could be scoring a good deal, but their devices might not function as in officially supported countries. Although there are many smartphones available in South Africa from numerous brands and at various price points, certain models popular elsewhere are not available locally. Among these devices are the Google Pixel and OnePlus ranges, as well as certain flagship models from locally represented brands like Xiaomi. Many of these smartphones are available to buy and ship directly from international websites, often at good prices. With more South Africans becoming comfortable with online shopping and using global e-commerce platforms, there could be a rise in smartphone imports.


Amazon.com makes buying these smartphones straightforward as it includes all shipping and taxes at checkout. However, there are several drawbacks to be aware of when buying them as opposed to shopping from a reputed local retailer.


The first major issue is that warranty claims could be expensive if a manufacturer does not have local support channels. If an imported smartphone has a hardware or software defect not caused by the user's mishandling, it may have to be repaired or replaced in its country of origin... Buying accessories or replacement parts for devices not widely sold in South Africa will also be more difficult or expensive.


The second big catch to look out for is whether the phone is unlocked to be compatible with South African cellular networks. There may be many instances where a device is restricted to country-specific networks... Fortunately, sellers on Amazon will clearly indicate if a device is unlocked and capable of working on networks outside the US...


However, even if you have checked the box on network compatibility, other features may not be supported or blocked in unofficially supported countries. This is particularly problematic on Google Pixel smartphones -- I recently discovered while importing
a Pixel 7 Pro... Although some apps available on the Play Store let users access VoLTE and VoWi-Fi in South Africa, 5G requires rooting or jailbreaking the Pixel, which may restrict access to certain apps and services.[...] Google's lack of 5G support
is unusual because most other Android phones with the capability work in South Africa, regardless of official local availability.[1][2]



Comments | View Source

entry.title: Damas-Hindley-Milner inference two ways
entry.summary: Damas-Hindley-Milner inference two ways
entry.content:
Max Bernstein has a blog post about implementing Damas-Hindley-Milner (HM) type inference in the programming language Scrapscript. From the article:


The core idea in HM is to generate type constraints based on how variables and other expressions are used together and then solve these constraints. These constraints are based on equality (as opposed to inequality, set subset, etc). For example, one might look at the expression a+b (where a and b are any expression, but in this case variables) and deduce that since + is a function that takes two ints and returns an int:


  • a must have type int
  • b must have type int
  • a+b must have type int

Perhaps, in the same example, later in a function, one might see f a (the application of the variable f to the argument a) and deduce that f must be a function. We can compose all of these constraints together to infer that f must be a function that can take an integer as an argument. Similarly, if we saw [a,c] (a list containing elements and c) and we require that our lists have homogeneous type elements, then we can add the constraint that [i]


The article also explains how they implemented it using Python code.

entry.title: Medical student's apparent celiac disease responded to giardiasis treatment
entry.summary: Medical student's apparent celiac disease responded to giardiasis treatment
entry.content:
An anonymous reader quotes a report from Backpacker:


Anders Johnson hadn't eaten gluten in nearly a decade. After coming down with an unidentifiable illness in the summer of 2006 while running high adventure trips at a Boy Scout camp in Southern California, he had been wracked with serious gastrointestinal dysfunction distress, depression, and brain fog. No matter how much he ate, he kept losing weight. At one point, he logged his caloric intake for a college nutrition class and found that he had been eating seven thousand calories a day, despite looking sickly thin. Around Thanksgiving of that year, it got so bad Johnson had to go to an urgent care because he was so dehydrated. "I ended up failing a good chunk of my classes that semester just because I didn't have any energy," Johnson says."Then I started hitting the doctors really hard, trying to figure it out."


Johnson's results came back borderline; not definitively positive, but not exactly negative either. He ran with it.


"I started eating gluten-free. I started regaining mental faculties and started getting a little bit of weight back on me," Johnson says "Whenever I cheated, it would just throw me back into a downward spiral." But doctors never definitively diagnosed Johnson with celiac disease... In 2015, however... a college friend who'd had [...] texted Johnson that she had eaten [...] cookie. As it turned out,[...] what that friend had assumed was celiac disease was [a\ very\ different\ illness:\ giardia\ (an
easily-treatable intestinal parasite)]. The chronic form of giardiasis is lesser known, however. The friend sent\nJohnson medical studies showing how chronic Giardia infection can cause celiac-like symptoms.["It was like a whole bunch of puzzle pieces fell into place at the same time,"]


said Johnson.


The issue was that he kept testing negative for giardiasis. Johnson wasn't convinced.


Johnson took pictures of his sample, along with the commercial one, and presented them to a doctor. ... Instead, the doctor prescribed him a cocktail [of antibiotics, antifungals,\ and antiprotozoal medications]. "If my intestines were warzone, we went full nuclear," Johnson remarked.\nA few weeks after the last round of medication, ... On the first round, after waiting 24 hours to see if he would have\n[...] reaction, ...


He could eat gluten again...


Dr. Leo Galland/span>, a doctor [of internal medicine-based practice focused on functional medicine/span>], describes people like Anders\nJohnson as having non-celiac gluten intolerance from chronic giardiasis.... Dr Galland also says that giardiasis can be hard to get accurate results for as well.... Chronic giardia,...can be particularly hard to identify....

entry.title: A deep dive into the iOS backup/restore system: The Sparserestore exploit
entry.summary: A deep dive into the iOS backup/restore system: The Sparserestore exploit
entry.content:
Many of the writeups reverse engineering the iOS backup system are outdated and do not necessarily represent how it works in modern day. They also tended to describe the structure of a backup file, but do not detail the on-device process of restoring a backup behind the scenes. The goal of this writeup is to document my findings on the backup system over the years and what I learned while developing Cowabunga Lite and Nugget. I will also be covering the Sparserestore exploit.


There is not a lot of documentation of how the backup domains map to the iOS file system, so I am compiling what I found here.


What is a domain? In a backup, domains tell iOS what files to restore and where. It is both a way of organization and a security measure. Having domains prevents attackers from using restores to write anywhere in the file system.


There are 2 different kinds of domains:


  1. The main type of domain is simply mapped to a file path (e.g., HomeDomain = /var/mobile) with some restrictions.


  2. The second type requires an extension: SysContainerDomain, SysSharedContainerDomain, or AppDomain. These have trailing dashes (-) where their extensions go; for example:


    • For SysContainerDomain or SysSharedContainerDomain, it's after that dash.


    • For AppDomains, it's after that dash + app bundle ID.


Outside of [the domain itself], [the path] will act like regular domains... There used to be a file in /System/Library/Backup/domains.plist that listed many paths & what could be backed up, but it was removed in iOS 17, seemingly correlated to separating /var & /var/mobile partitions... A markdown version can be found in Domains.md if you would like more about what can & cannot be restored in each domain.[...]


The article goes into much greater detail about Apple's changes made with its latest OS update — including "many modifications" made specifically for backups — as well as details about restoring specific types data such as media, preferences, health information etc.


But perhaps most interestingly they discuss an exploit called Sparserestore, which allowed users "to continuously go back" through directories until reaching root level access:


"The Sparserestore exploit is very simple at its core," writes developer Lemin Limez on GitHub:


It uses backpathing [..] allowing you write anywhere on /var partition that's not SSV protected.... After -, you are currently in directory: /private/var/.backup.i/var/root/Library/Backup/SystemContainers/Data/... This your starting path... Once you reach root\, you can place any filepath afterwards.... At end restore\, we crash by restoring directly /private`. Normally, crash cancel would no files change. However, using exploit, files still restored. This has added benefit skipping setup entirely without having modify files like Cowabunga Lite...


Apple patched this vulnerability last year during beta testing for its next major release (i.e., iOS 18), restricting all domains from containing slashes ("/").


You can read more here (or check out Limez's full post via his GitHub page):


A deep dive into the iOS backup/restore system · GitHub



Comments | View Source

entry.title: Popups and Menus in Qt Quick 6.8
entry.summary: Popups and Menus in Qt Quick 6.8
entry.content:
Qt Quick 6.8 introduces the ability to create top-level popups, dialogs, tooltips, and menus in dedicated windows using a new popupType property. This feature allows developers to achieve a more native desktop application experience similar to Qt Widgets applications.


Up until now, the only way to achieve the same kind of top-level popup windows in Qt Quick, were to create custom components based on Window... In Qt 6.8, it's finally possible to have Popup, Dialogs, ToolTips, and Menus inside top-level windows. This can be controlled by the new popupType property...


Windows also supports native WIN32 context menus [that] might appear somewhat outdated, and Popup.Window can be used instead, for a more consistent look on modern platforms... On macOS, we've finally added support for native menu bars! You will never have to choose between the QtQuick.Controls and Qt.labs.platform menu bars ever again...

entry.title: National Archives Pushes Google Gemini AI on Employees
entry.summary: National Archives Pushes Google Gemini AI on Employees
entry.content:
In June, the U.S. National Archives and Records Administration (NARA) gave employees a presentation and tech demo called "AI-mazing Tech-venture" in which Google's Gemini AI was presented as a tool archives employees could use to "enhance productivity." During a demo, the AI was queried with questions about the John F. Kennedy assassination, according to a copy of the presentation obtained by 404 Media using a public records request. In December, NARA plans to launch a public-facing AI-powered chatbot called "Archie AI," 404 Media has learned.


"The National Archives has big plans for AI," a NARA spokesperson told 404 Media. "It's going to be essential to how we conduct our work, how we scale our services for Americans who want to be able to access our records from anywhere, anytime, and how we ensure that we are ready to care for the records being created today and in the future."


Employee chat logs given during the presentation show that National Archives employees are concerned about the idea that AI tools will be used in archiving, a practice that is inherently concerned with accurately recording history.


One worker who attended the presentation told 404 Media “I suspect they're going to introduce it [Gemini] into workplace. I'm just a person who works there and hates [AI] bullshit.” The presentation was given about a month after NARA banned employees from using ChatGPT because it said it posted an “unacceptable risk" [to data security], and cautioned them not to rely on LLMs for factual information...


During the demonstration of Google’s Vertex AI — which allows organizations like NARA train large language models on their own datasets — one employee asked: “How would [the] public know they are receiving response from actual archivist or not generative A.I.? Would N.A.R.A disclose what aspects of reference are generated from A.I?” Two other employees followed up saying they were also concerned this might lower trust in institution if not properly disclosed...



Comments | View Source

entry.title: Plutocrat Archipelagos
entry.summary: Plutocrat Archipelagos
entry.content:
Long-time Slashdot reader jones_supa shares a report from MacGuffin Magazine:


Razor wire fences, galvanized spikes and electrified perimeters: the barriers that entomb the ultra-rich in their walled settlements isolate them from perpetual violence and societal collapse.


I have had the opportunity to meet a surprisingly large number of ultra-high net worth individuals over the years -- not through any particular personal desire, I hasten to add. A few of these people I've merely met in passing, typically at some event held by a cultural institution. However, I have come to know several others quite well, as either friends or as employers. (I am specifically speaking about four of the world's 2,781 billionaires).


Regardless of whether they are 'self made' or 'second gen', the ultra-rich have unique psychological profiles amongst the general populace. In my experience, both categories of billionaire are dominated by interminable existential crises -- although each displays nuance when it comes to confrontation. The 'self made' have a tendency towards aggressive megalomania, while 'second gens' demur in favour of nihilistic hedonism.


The article goes on to describe how "the unjustifiably wealthy are unfit for rule," adding that "it is impossible for such people to go on holiday." From there:


\begin{quote}
We are living through a period of societal collapse... We are living through the most dangerous phase of modernity, when those in power will do anything they can to preserve an increasingly fragile status quo... Perhaps as modernity gives way to the next paradigm (we are already in a new Renaissance), there will not be more or less violence than under late capitalism. This might mean that [...] we might not see [...] uncontrolled climate migration largely assumed to accompany the collapse [...]. On the other hand, although [...] it may well be that only descendants inherit Earth.\end{quote}



Comments | View Source

entry.title: Petroleum Drilling Technology Is Now Making Carbon-Free Power
entry.summary: Petroleum Drilling Technology Is Now Making Carbon-Free Power
entry.content:
An anonymous reader quotes a report from NPR:


There's a valley in rural southwest Utah that's become a hub for renewable energy. Dozens of tall white wind turbines whoosh up in the sky. A sea of solar panels glistens in the distance. But the new kid on the block is mostly hidden underground. From the surface, Fervo Energy's Cape Station looks more or less like an oil derrick, with a thin metal tower rising above the sagebrush steppe. But this $2 billion geothermal project, which broke ground last year, is not drilling for gas. It's drilling for underground heat that CEO Tim Latimer believes holds the key to generating carbon-free power -- lots of it.


"Just these three well pads alone will produce 100 megawatts of electricity," he said. "Around-the-clock, 24/7 electricity." Latimer stood overlooking the project, which is currently under construction, on one of the drill rig's metal platforms 40 feet off the ground...


The U.S Department of Energy found that geothermal energy could provide up to 120 gigawatts (or about 16% percent) of America's anticipated electricity needs by 2050.


But traditional technologies can only be deployed economically in areas where underground heat is easily accessible, according to Google and Fervo co-founder Tim Latimer.


"That's not a statement you could have made two or three years ago," he said...
Fervo signed a landmark deal with Southern California Edison this summer; it will send its first batch of geothermal juice to SoCal Edison's grid in 2026...


California leaders set a mandate in 2018 requiring [...] 100% renewable electricity by [...]. SoCal Edison spokesperson Reggie Kumar said adding geothermal makes sense: "For California to achieve its decarbonization goals by [2045], we need more clean firm resources."


The article also notes how enhanced geothermal systems are being pioneered at Utah FORGE (Frontier Observatory for Research in Geothermal Energy), funded with $220 million from DOE back in 2018:


The mission isn't to produce its own electricity; it's to test tools and techniques through trial and error and answer
the big question: Can you pipe cool water through cracks in hot underground rock and create a geothermal plant almost
anywhere? That idea is known as an enhanced geothermal system... Six years after drilling began,[...] they proved for
the first time they could pump water from one well, through underground cracks, into another well...


Other than creating those cracks, McLennan said, there would be no significant difference between what they're doing
at FORGE today versus what oil companies were doing here decades ago when they were looking for fossil fuels...

entry.title: OpenTelemetry Challenges: Handling Long-Running Spans
entry.summary: OpenTelemetry Challenges: Handling Long-Running Spans
entry.content:
Long-running spans are one of my biggest "we don't really actually have a good standard solution for this" issues in opentelemetry. They're something I've run into before, weirdly frequently, and especially so when attempting to try and instrument front-end or mobile facing systems. It turns out, though, that the issues here with long running spans are actually pretty similar to the issues with interrupted, partial, or unclosed spans. In fact, they're really mostly the same thing (with the added bonus that if you do tail sampling your sampling decision is going to happen before the span ends, which exacerbates the problem by turning functioning spans into partial and broken ones) [writes Hazel Weakly at The New Stack].


Anyway, I talk about this and more in this article and even point out a really cool solution from Embrace that addresses this in an opentelemetry compatible way (hint: does the phrase "write ahead log" make you quiver with excitement? If so, you should definitely read this).

entry.title: How the Richest People Can Access Billions Without Selling Their Stock
entry.summary: How the Richest People Can Access Billions Without Selling Their Stock
entry.content:
Many of the country’s richest people, including Elon Musk and Larry Ellison, borrow against their stock while avoiding capital gains taxes. Forbes reports on how this works:


When the world’s richest man wants cash, he can simply borrow money by putting up -- or pledging -- some of his Tesla shares as collateral for lines of credit, instead of selling shares and paying capital gains taxes. These pledged shares serve as an evergreen credit facility, giving Musk access to cash when he needs it. Musk currently has pledged 88.3 million Tesla shares, nearly 36.2% of his overall stake (excluding options), as of Wednesday worth more than $94 billion.


Musk is one of 32 billionaires identified in the Forbes 400 list who are pledging public stock as collateral for current or potential lines of credit; others include Oracle chairman Larry Ellison, Walmart heir Jim Walton and private equity's Stephen Schwarzman.


Across all companies listed on the NYSE and Nasdaq exchanges, there are 560 executive officers and directors and 5%+ shareholders currently pledging shares; the size of the average pledge is $427 million and the aggregate value of these pledged shares is $239 billion...


Most larger companies don't allow pledging: Over two-thirds (68.4%) of S&P 500 companies ban all company employees and shareholders from pledging shares for debt...

entry.title: Correct eye contact in videos by redirecting the eyes to look at the camera
entry.summary: Correct eye contact in videos by redirecting the eyes to look at the camera
entry.content:
Sieve's Eye Contact Correction API is a fast and high-quality eye contact correction API built for developers. Eye contact correction is a technique for ensuring that the eyes in a video appear to be looking at the camera, even when the subject is not actually looking at it. This is achieved by redirecting the eyes to simulate eye contact with the camera.


The Eye Contact Correction API can correct gaze in videos while preserving original blinking and head movements, allowing you to create more natural-looking videos. Pricing starts at $0.10 per minute of video processed.


Here's how Sieve describes its technology:


The input must be a video file (image files are not supported). Processing time depends on the video length and resolution; longer or higher-resolution videos will take more time to process. The accuracy_boost option provides more precise results but may increase processing time as well.


For any issues or questions, please get in touch with contact@sievedata.com.
